questions.question: What should you set up BEFORE starting any AWS development work?
questions.explanation: Setting up billing alerts and budgets should be your FIRST action. This protects you from unexpected charges and surprise bills, especially when learning AWS.

questions.question: What types of Free Tier offers does AWS provide? (Select ALL that apply)
questions.explanation: AWS Free Tier has three types: Always Free (Lambda, DynamoDB limits), 12 Months Free for new accounts (EC2, S3), and Short-term Trials for specific services. There's no unlimited free tier.

questions.question: Match each resource with its common cost trap:
rightColumn: Charges when not attached to running instance
questions.explanation: NAT Gateway costs ~$32/month minimum. Unused Elastic IPs incur charges. CloudWatch Logs accumulate forever unless you set retention. Cross-AZ transfer costs $0.01/GB each way.

questions.question: What does this command prevent?
options: Lambda functions from running longer than 7 days
CloudWatch Logs from accumulating indefinitely (sets 7-day retention)
API calls older than 7 days from being logged
IAM sessions from lasting longer than 7 days
questions.explanation: This sets a 7-day retention policy on CloudWatch Logs. By default, logs are kept forever and can accumulate significant storage costs. Set retention based on your compliance and debugging needs.

questions.question: Data transfer INTO AWS from the internet is generally free.
questions.explanation: Inbound data transfer from the internet to AWS is typically free. However, outbound transfer TO the internet costs money ($0.09/GB for the first 10TB). Cross-region and cross-AZ transfers also have costs.

questions.question: How can you reduce costs when a Lambda in a VPC needs to access DynamoDB?
options: Create a VPC Endpoint for DynamoDB (~$7/month)
questions.explanation: VPC Endpoints provide private access to AWS services without NAT Gateway. They're much cheaper (~$7/month vs $32+/month for NAT) and keep traffic within AWS network.
